image.altText: Australia batter Pat Cummins shouts in joy after winning an Ashes Test at Edgbaston.

items.synopsis: Pat Cummins leads Australia to a stunning victory in the first Ashes Test, chasing down 281 with just two wickets left inside the final five overs at Edgbaston.

title.children: Pat Cummins leads Australia to miraculous Ashes victory with thrilling run chase at Edgbaston

image.altText: A wide shot of the District Court in Perth with two men walking towards its doors.

items.synopsis: A "hardened" Perth judge says she was "shocked" by the level of offending from the man, as she jails him for more than two decades. WARNING: This story contains distressing content.

title.children: 'Disgusting, violent and depraved': Perth man jailed for 'horrendous' sexual abuse of stepdaughter

image.altText: A road sign showing kangaroos in the area.

items.synopsis: Commercial kangaroo shooters are regulated under a national code that's supposed to protect animal welfare, but activists say what happens in rural Australia at night can be in breach of it, putting the industry under threat.

title.children: 'Some sort of massacre': Why global footwear giants are ditching roo shoes

image.altText: England fielder Ben Stokes drops the ball as he hits the ground.

items.synopsis: Australia wins a thrilling Ashes Test to gain an early advantage over England and the Bazball phenomena. Here are the main talking points from an enthralling day of cricket.

title.children: Five quick hits — Ben Stokes grabs the game by the scruff of the neck  … and then drops it

image.altText: Australia batter Pat Cummins holds up a bat and stump after winning an Ashes Test at Edgbaston.

items.synopsis: A mention of Edgbaston once sent a shiver down Australian spines. But from this day on, it will forever be the scene of Pat Cummins's greatest stand and one of Australia's greatest Ashes triumphs.

title.children: Pat Cummins conquers England, reclaims Edgbaston and leads his Australia to history

image.altText: Aerial view of rows of new houses in outer suburbia.

items.synopsis: Banks and financial counsellors are urging borrowers to take action before they miss home loan repayments. Here are some of the options you might have if it's becoming difficult to keep up with your mortgage.

title.children: 'It's time for people to ask, is this an affordable mortgage for us?': Experts offer financial hardship tips

image.altText: A rainbow-coloured sign advertising the cancellation of an event.

items.synopsis: When organisers first convinced traditionally conservative parts of the country to host a Pride ball, it was celebrated as a win for inclusion. Now thriving, these events are increasingly facing a new and sinister threat.

title.children: 'Uptick' in conspiracy theorists, far-right groups targeting councils to shut down Pride events

image.altText: A cylindrical white metal underwater craft floats in a dark blue mass of water.

items.synopsis: Search efforts are continuing for five people missing in a deep-ocean submersible in the northern Atlantic, with rescuers in a race against time as oxygen levels dwindle.

title.children: All passengers on board missing Titanic submersible identified as breathable air dwindles

image.altText: Plane crashed into bushes

items.synopsis: One person has been seriously injured after a light plane crash near Derby.

title.children: Authorities investigating light plane crash in WA's far north

image.altText: Lea Russ lying in a hospital bed, with multiple IV tubes hooked up to one arm.

items.synopsis: Patients who need to see a GP urgently are increasingly waiting more than 24 hours to be seen. But they may not know that general practices are meant to offer emergency bookings.

title.children: Lea called her GP in tears and in agony. Like many patients, she couldn't get in for weeks

image.altText: Yunupingu with Gumatj children at Garma in 2019.

items.synopsis: Late Gumatj clan leader Yunupingu won a historic legal battle that could have significant implications for compensation claims across Australia. The Commonwealth is now appealing.

title.children: Commonwealth lodges High Court challenge to landmark $700 million native title compensation claim

image.altText: A blastoid or embryoid

items.synopsis: Reports that scientists are making "synthetic embryos" has revived debate about stem cell research. But what exactly is going on?

title.children: Scientists created 'synthetic embryos' without sperm or eggs. What are the legal and ethical implications?

image.altText: A slow shutter photograph showing a blurry market trading board at the Australia Securities Exchange.

items.synopsis: It has been red across the board on global markets, with China's rate cut disappointing and traders awaiting testimony from the Federal Reserve chair. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: ASX to follow global markets lower, Aussie dollar falls

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: As interest rates have risen, the banks have pointed out that many borrowers have built up buffers while on low fixed rates and are well ahead on their home loans, in some cases by years. But that's of little comfort to those who are starting to struggle to repay, and each rate rise adds only more pressure to those households. So what should you do if you're at risk of falling behind or have even missed a repayment? I spoke to banks, financial counsellors and the industry ombudsman about the steps you can take: The message from banks is get in touch early and speak to their hardship teams about temporary changes that can be made to your loan, if you're likely to be able to get back on track with some short-term assistance. Free financial counselling services can be accessed by calling the National Debt Helpline on 1800 007 007 — they can help you take a look at your broader financial picture and whether you can afford your mortgage and other debts. And if you're unhappy with how your bank has handled the situation, you can lodge a complaint with the Australian Financial Complaints Authority, which will look into the issue. A pause will be put on any action your lender is taking while they're notified and the matter is investigated. Read more here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: When should you ask for help with your home loan?

featuredLink.title: 'It's time for people to ask, is this an affordable mortgage for us?': Experts offer financial hardship tips

children.content: As interest rates have risen, the banks have pointed out that many borrowers have built up buffers while on low fixed rates and are well ahead on their home loans, in some cases by years.
But that's of little comfort to those who are starting to struggle to repay, and each rate rise adds only more pressure to those households.
So what should you do if you're at risk of falling behind or have even missed a repayment?
I spoke to banks, financial counsellors and the industry ombudsman about the steps you can take:

hardship teams
about temporary changes that can be made to your loan, if you're likely to be able to get back on track with some short-term assistance.
Free financial counselling services can be accessed by calling the

And if you're unhappy with how your bank has handled the situation, you can lodge a complaint with the

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning! But not such a good one for stocks… Stephanie Chalmers here to bring you all the day's news, and it's been a down night for markets in Europe and the US. That's got our futures pointing to falls when the ASX opens later this morning. The Australian dollar fell throughout yesterday and overnight, to below 68 US cents, while the US dollar edged up. The retreat for the Aussie dollar began after yesterday's RBA meeting minutes, while the ASX 200 hit a nine-week high. It also comes ahead of a closely-watched testimony by US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell before congress tomorrow. Another focus for markets is the People's Bank of China, which cut its key lending rate on Tuesday, but not by as much as some had expected. "These cuts will lower the cost of new loans, as well as interest payments on existing loans," said Julian Evans-Pritchard, head of China economics at Capital Economics. "That should offer some modest support to economic activit y. But we think it is unlikely to drive a sharp acceleration in credit growth, given weak credit demand." We'll bring you more news throughout the day, so stick with us!
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Red across the board for global markets

image.altText: police crash investigators inspect the  road at the site of a crash

items.synopsis: The NSW government orders its Bus Industry Taskforce to review concerns around seat belt use, driver training and fatigue and safety management.

title.children: Urgent review ordered into NSW bus safety after fatal Hunter Valley crash

image.altText: A black and white photo of a man with a guitar and a white shirt with blood stains

items.synopsis: An inquiry hears a NSW Police task force ruled there was "insufficient information" to establish whether the former AC/DC manager's death was a hate crime but it had not tested his blood-stained clothes.

title.children: Former AC/DC manager Crispin Dye's bloody clothes weren't tested through three police probes and a coronial inquest

image.altText: Apryl Watson stands holding a framed photo of her mother, Tanya Day, in a Melbourne garden.

items.synopsis: Indigenous and non-Indigenous deaths in custody will be reported in real time from today as part of a federal government attempt to address the number of people dying behind bars.

title.children: Federal government introduces real-time reporting of deaths in custody

image.altText: Coins and notes in a till.

items.synopsis: Like cheques, cash will probably die gradually, then suddenly. By the time it does, there will be few users left who care, writes Peter Martin.

title.children: An astounding chart shows how the way Australians pay has completely changed in a generation

image.altText: Children and staff are seen around a rug while playing at a childcare centre.

items.synopsis: Hundreds of families are advised their childcare fees will increase alongside the rollout of higher subsidies, prompting concerns the move is "opportunistic".

title.children: Families expecting savings from childcare subsidies hit with fee hikes

image.altText: Ice

items.synopsis: A Tasmanian inquiry hears disturbing accounts of children being injected and given ice by parents wanting them to commit crimes.

title.children: 'You poor little thing': Parents injecting kids with ice to commit crimes, inquiry hears

image.altText: A man stands at a window looking outside.

items.synopsis: Australia's Human Rights Commissioner criticises an over-reliance on hotels for use in immigration detention, and the often-lengthy stays many detainees are subjected to.

title.children: 'Not under any circumstances': Human Rights Commissioner criticises lengthy stays in hotel detention

image.altText: A older man smiles while looking at a younger man

items.synopsis: US President Joe Biden's son Hunter Biden agrees to plead guilty on three federal tax and firearm charges in a deal with the Justice Department.

title.children: Hunter Biden takes plea deal on federal tax and firearm charges

image.altText: Xi Jinping standing in front of a Chinese flag.

items.synopsis: A major new opinion poll shows Australians have warmed slightly to China over the past year, while a majority are glad to see high-level political contact between Canberra and Beijing resume.

title.children: Poll finds most Australians glad relations with China thawing, but still don't trust Xi Jinping

image.altText: Antony Blinken shakes hands with Xi Jinping.

items.synopsis: Both sides have stressed the importance of dialogue in order to avoid confrontation. But can US-China relations continue to improve, asks David SG Goodman.

title.children: China and the US are talking again. But it's what preceded their meeting that's most significant

image.altText: A man in a blue checkered shirt holding a small cactus smiles standing among tall green cacti.

items.synopsis: Mescaline, the hallucinogenic substance in some cacti, is illegal to use. But with the recent medical approval of other similar psychedelics, this scientist wants more research on the plant.

title.children: Could this psychedelic plant help treat anxiety and depression? Liam wants more research to on it

image.altText: Close photo of Cynthia Dearborn with shoulder-length grey hair and neutral expression.

items.synopsis: Cynthia's relationship with her father was one of love but also fear. It meant suddenly becoming his carer was tough.

title.children: How Cynthia managed to find 'beautiful, tender moments' while caring for her once-abusive father

image.altText: Josh makes a peace sign while wearing formal attire

items.synopsis: Cracks in the National Disability Insurance Scheme contributed to the death of a 24-year-old man who died after being handcuffed at Perth's underground train station, according to a disability advocate.

title.children: 'Josh didn't have support': Gaps in NDIS contributed to death of man at train station, disability advocate says

image.altText: Police officers walking next to Andrew Tate in a blue hooded jumper

items.synopsis: Romanian prosecutors send social media influencer Andrew Tate, his brother Tristan, and two other suspects to trial on charges of human trafficking and forming a criminal gang to sexually exploit women.

title.children: Social media personality Andrew Tate to face trial for rape and human trafficking

image.altText: A woman in a dark shirt speaking to Netbal players in red shirts.

items.synopsis: The Adelaide Thunderbirds are back from the netball wilderness after a four-year rebuild by coach Tania Obst, turning the side from the competition's easybeats to a team that is now just two wins from claiming a fifth flag.

title.children: From 27 losses in a row, back to the finals. How a netball legend rebuilt an Australian sporting powerhouse

image.altText: A large pink fish swims underwater.

items.synopsis: In a partial backdown over contentious demersal fishing bans, the government will allow charter operators to catch and cook certain species on their boats.

title.children: Fishing charter operators split on WA government's proposed 'catch and cook' scheme

image.altText: Older male cotton grower stands in cotton field looking off into the distance wearing colourful shirt and dark green jacket

items.synopsis: Cotton is known as a desert crop, but farms are appearing in unexpected regions across Queensland — even in traditional cane country.

title.children: Jeff used to grow pineapples and cane, but five years ago he became a coastal cotton pioneer

image.altText: Qatar player

items.synopsis: Yusuf Abdurisag, the Qatari soccer player accused of a racist comment that caused a match against New Zealand to be abandoned, hits back at the claims.

title.children: Qatar claims player accused of racial abuse was actually target of vilification from NZ players

image.altText: Indigenous rock art painting of hands and a kookaburra in a cave at Carnarvon Gorge

items.synopsis: Indigenous leaders and local rangers say the lengths people will go to for the perfect photograph at Carnarvon Gorge are disrespectful and unlawful.

title.children: Social media influencers ruining ancient Indigenous art at Carnarvon Gorge, rangers say
